intro: Miconia cazaletii, commonly known as the Brazilian starfruit, is a member of the Melastomataceae family and is native to the Atlantic Forest of Brazil. It is a small to medium-sized evergreen shrub or tree that can grow up to 6 meters tall. The plant is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves with a glossy surface and prominent veins. Its flowers are showy, with five white petals and a yellow center, and it produces small, round fruits that are edible when ripe. The species is also noted for its ability to thrive in shaded environments and its role in local ecosystems.
